titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Called this morning upon the ministers Alvensleben and Haugwitz, and informed them I had received the ratification of the Treaty, and should be ready to exchange it for theirs whenever it would be convenient for them— They told me that they would give me notice, as soon as possible after the king’s return which is to be on the 8th: or 9th: of this month— Rode out this afternoon with Mrs. A. who is quite unwell— Received letters this Evening from Mr: King, and from my brother Thomas.

2. Called this forenoon upon Mr: Paleske, at the hotel de Russie— Mrs: Adams went in the afternoon to Charlottenburg with Mrs: Brown— Evening at Princess Henry’s.— Play’d Casino with Madame de Blumenthal, the Minister Heinitz, and Count Bünau— Stay’d to supper— Convers’d with the french Secretary of legation Bignon— And likewise with General Beurnonville, who is not satisfied with this Government.
3. At Mr: Schickler’s counting house this morning, and again in the afternoon. Took a couple of bills upon England. Called on Mr: Richards— Mr: Paleske dined with us— Thunder-shower this Evening.

4. Wrote several letters— Mrs: Adams and myself came after dinner to Potsdam, upon a tour of a few days for the benefit of her health— We travell’d the distance in three hours & a half, with our own horses.— Took a walk round the town in the evening— Had one of the most violent thunder storms I ever witness’d in Europe.

5. We pass’d this day at Potsdam to allow our horses to rest— The weather was very warm— Walk’d alone in the forenoon—and towards evening with Mrs: Adams— Finish’d the translation of the 13th: Satyre of Juvenal.

6. At about 7. o’clock this morning we set out from Potsdam to go to Brandenburg. The distance is between four and five German miles; but our coachman by missing the way, lengthened it at least a mile more. Mrs: Adams was unwell even before we left the inn, and soon became very ill— I wish’d to return but she insisted upon going forward, untill at about one afternoon we were obliged to stop in a miserable village, where we could find no house where she could have a room, but at the clergyman’s. His name is Volk, and the village — his wife was extremely kind and obliging, and would accept nothing for their trouble— Mrs: A. continued very ill, untill about 3—when she recovered so far as to be able to proceed— At Grossen Kreutz—two miles from Brandenburg, we took four post-horses, and reach’d Brandenburg at about six o’clock. Mrs: A— was very much recovered; so as to be able to take a short walk in the town— We had a shower in the afternoon, and the Evening was very cool.

7. We spent the day at Brandenburg the antient Capital of this country, and the city from which the whole Margraviate takes its name. It is of course quite an old, and in some sort a deserted town; yet it is not easy to conceive why it was abandoned by the Government for Berlin, the situation of which is not so pleasant. We walk’d round the town both in the forenoon and afternoon; and in the evening I took a walk alone, Mrs: Adams not being yet wholly recover’d from her severe illness of yesterday— We lodg’d at the sign of the white Horse, in the new town.

8. At 8 o’clock this morning we left Brandenburg, with a couple of post-horses leading our own; and reach’d Potsdam at about four in the afternoon— Mrs: A— was very well during the ride, but so much fatigued as to have an indifferent evening— We took a short walk however out of the town— Read a little of Mrs: Radcliff’s Mysteries of Udolpho; but in general I have read little upon this journey.— I have written however, more than usual.

9. We had intended to pass this night at Potsdam, and return to-morrow morning; but the weather being cool, and the place very dull, we concluded to go home this evening— Just at 5 we set out, and reach’d our own house, soon after 8— The tour would have been more agreeable, had Mrs: A. not suffered so much illness, while we were making it— But I hope it will in the end be serviceable to her health; and in other respects it has been pleasant.

10. Mr: Arbuthnot called this afternoon to pay us a visit. Resumed my usual regular occupations. Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s— I was there a couple of hours likewise— Sir Francis Vincent, an English Baronet was there— He goes to-morrow morning for Dresden and Vienna.— Began an attempt upon the 14th: Satire of Juvenal.

11. The vicomte d’Anadia called upon me this forenoon, with a letter from Mr: Platner, a merchant of Trieste, who wishes to be appointed American consul at that port.— Wrote a short letter to the Secy: of State, and walk’d as usual before and after dinner.
12. Mrs: A— called this evening to see Mrs: O’Farril, but found her not at home. Spent the Evening therefore at Doctor Brown’s, where we found Mr: Arbuthnot— They had a fire.
13. I am busied almost exclusively in copying; my translations of Juvenal’s 13th: Satire and of the Oberon. Called at the Casino before dinner— Long walks in the park; and by no means idle ones.

14. Letters to my mother and brother, and to the Secretary of State— Was at the Casino before dinner; and almost the whole afternoon and evening in the park.— Rain this Evening and the weather very cold.

15. Cold— Rainy day— Received a letter from Mr: Gentz with four copies of his essay upon the American and french Revolutions— Went to the play this Evening with Mrs: Adams, and saw Weiberlist, the female stratagem. The music is of Cimarosa, and very good. General Beurnonville & his aids were with us in the box.

16. Cold and rainy weather continues. Mrs: Adams went this evening again to the play, and took Epps with her. I took my long walks in the park. Write a great deal, whether to any purpose or not. my translations from Juvenal are at least an amusement to myself.

17. Letter to my brother Thomas enclosing one from Mrs: A. to her sister. Continue my copying and my translations. It leaves me very little time to write any thing else— Mrs: A— this Evening at Dr: Brown’s— I was there about an hour.

18. Writing to my father.— Somewhat unwell— The 14th: Satire of Juvenal which I am now translating is much inferior to the 13th:— Walking this evening, I was overtaken by the rain— Weather still very cold.

19. Count and Countess Bruhl, and their daughter Mary, General O’Farril, his lady & her son, The Vicomte d’Anadia, Count Bunau, Messrs: d’Araujo and d’Aguilar, Dr: Brown and Margarett & Pauline Neale: dined with us to day— Miss Bruhl, went to be presented in the evening at Maid of honour to the queen mother.— I took my usual evening walk in the park.

20. Mr: Oliver, Mr: Ogden, and Mr: Fulton, three young Americans called upon me this morning. The first We had seen the last autumn at Dresden; and the second brought me a letter of introduction from Mr Pitcairn. They propose staying here only a day or two. Dined at the Minister Alvensleben’s, with a diplomatic company of 24 persons— Walk’d afterwards to Charlottenburg where I found Mrs: A. and Mrs: Brown.

21. Mr: Engel called this morning, with a letter for my brother Thomas— Messrs: Oliver, Ogden and Fulton dined with us— They go to-morrow morning to Potsdam— Long walk; afterwards in the evening at Dr: Brown’s.

22. Dined with Mr: Garlike— After dinner walk’d to Charlottenburg— Found Mrs: A. there— The two Miss Brühl’s; and the Minister Alvensleben— Walk’d home, likewise. Found letters from England &c. And a notification from Count Haugwitz to call on him to morrow and exchange the ratifications of the Treaty.

23. Had a sleepless, restless, feverish night, and was unwell all this day. At half-past one, I went and exchanged the ratifications of the Treaty with Count Haugwitz; who offered me a snuff-box with the king’s picture set round in diamonds, in the king’s name upon the occasion; which of course I declined; but at his strong solicitation consented to write and request leave of Congress to accept it, which I told him I was sure would be refused— Countess Brühl, and her daughter Mary took tea, and spent part of the evening with Mrs: Adams. I read to them the first book of my translation of Oberon, with which I am now wholly dissatisfied. My translation from Juvenal is almost wholly suspended.

24. Wrote to the Secretary of State— Took a short walk this afternoon. Evening at a party at Madame de Saldern’s— With this she begins her weekly parties for the summer— Play’d whist with Countess Haugwitz, Madame de Blumenthal, and the chevalier d’Aguilar— Called afterwards at Dr: Brown’s for Mrs: A. who spent the Evening there— Mrs: Brown very unwell.

25. At the Casino this forenoon. Called upon Mr: Arbuthnot who is going in a few days to England.— In the evening at a party at the Minister Heinitz’s, upon the marriage of Miss Zedritz to Count Hardenberg. Mrs: Adams went, but stayed only about an hour— I play’d whist, with Mad: Lubinska, Mlle: de Hoorn and M: de Knoblesdorf; and came away before supper.— The bride and bridegroom play’d cards together, with Prince Augustus Ferdinand, and Madame de Haugwitz. Their playing together is according to the custom of the country.

26. Dined with the portuguese Minister, the vicomte d’Anadia; with nearly the same company we had last week— He shewed us his library and his paintings— Long walk in the park. Mrs: Adams very unwell this evening.

27. Mrs: A— is much better— Writing to the Secretary of States. Walk, again in the park, and resume a little the Juvenal which has been for some time neglected. Evening latter part at Dr: Brown’s. Mrs: Brown quite unwell— We met there Mrs: Schickler and Miss Brandt.

28. Finish’d the translation of Gentz’s parallel between the American and french revolutions— Spent the Evening and supp’d at Mr: Schickler’s, who goes with his wife next monday, for Hamburg— Play’d Boston with Madame Strickhuysen, Baron Krudener and Count Wartensleben.

29. Took a ride with Mrs: Adams this afternoon to Pankau, a village about four english miles out of town. resume, the copy of my Oberon, which I have intermitted for some days past— Compared a Satire of Donne with the versification of it by Pope.

30. Finish’d the 14th: Satire of Juvenal, which is inferior in every respect to the 13th:— Took a ride this afternoon with Mrs: Adams to the village of Frederic’sfeldt—about four miles out of town, on the Frankfort road— News of the battle of Maringo.

Day. Rise between 6 and 8 very irregularly—write untill nearly ten; either translating, or copying off the Oberon.— Breakfast— Write letters, or continue to copy or translate untill two— Walk an hour in the park. Dine— After dinner an hour or two of leisure— Walk, two or three hours more in the park— Home at about 9. Write down the lines I made in walking— Bed at about 11.— To this regularity, there have been exceptions this month during five days when we made our tour to Potsdam and Brandenburg; and during about ten days together when I had constantly company at home, or dined out myself.— In the course of the month I have translated Gentz’s essay, and Juvenal’s 14th: Satire.
